text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

On October 1, 2014, Real Estate and Facilities Management (REFM) merged with Physical Security and Emergency Preparedness (PSEP) to create Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS). This IRM has been updated to reﬂect current organization titles.
As of January

, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) instituted a requirement that the IRM addresses relevant internal controls. This will inform employees about the importance of and for internal controls by describing the program objectives and officials charged with program management and oversight. Internal controls are the program’s policies and procedures which

As of January 1, 2017, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) instituted a requirement that the IRM addresses relevant internal controls. This will inform employees about the importance of and for internal controls by describing the program objectives and officials charged with program management and oversight. Internal controls are the program’s policies and procedures which

a. Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms deﬁned. b. Program goals are established and performance is measured to assess the efficient effective mission and objective accomplishment. c. Program and resources are protected against waste, fraud, abuse, mismanagement misappropriation. d. Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. e. Financial reporting is complete, current and accurate. f. Reliable information is obtained and used for decision making and quality assurance.
Added the additional authority, GSA Leasing Desk Guide, to IRM 1.14.6.6(d).
This IRM supersedes IRM 1.14.6 dated July 08,
Facilities Management and Security Services
Richard L. Rodriguez Director Facilities Management and Security Agency
Wide Shared Services
Table of Contents
Program

) FMSS provides Real Property Management (RPM) program support to all entities of the IRS and provides: a. management of all space occupied by IRS. b. Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) and guidance for the use of all space. c. strategic portfolio planning to assist IRS entities with short and housing needs. d. acquisition of space through the General Services Administration other governmental entities and IRS Lease Contracting Officers under authority delegated by GSA. e. space planning and design services for new space. f. alterations and reconﬁguration of existing space. (
) Purpose: This IRM provides information pertinent to the operation of the FMSS RPM Program. (
) Audience: FMSS. (
) Policy Owner: Director, FMSS. (
) Program Owner: Associate Director, RPM, FMSS. (
) Primary Stakeholders: FMSS employees. (

) This IRM provides the purpose, program description, objectives, directives, sponsibilities, and authorities for the Real Property Management Program. section is primarily for the use of space management personnel in FMSS. (

) The objectives of the FMSS RPM Program are to: a. facilitate quality customer service and the collection of taxes by offices that are convenient and accessible to the public. b. enhance productivity through a quality work environment that is secure and comfortable. c. provide portfolio ﬂexibility to accommodate program variability. d. foster effective space utilization. e. provide the most cost effective housing for IRS by utilizing telework gies, workstation sharing, universal workstation designs, and other alternative workspace arrangements for out of office employees, where applicable. f. ensure accurate charges for IRS space under the Federal Buildings Rent system and GSA space pricing policy, including negotiation of IRS Occupancy Agreements (OA). (

) GSA prescribes the procedures and methods governing the acquisition, tion, assignment, pricing, and release of IRS space in government-owned leased buildings controlled by GSA, or delegated to IRS, in the United (
) GSA performs all functions associated with the acquisition of leasehold in real property for IRS, except as otherwise speciﬁed in GSA Federal Man- agement Regulations (FMR) Bulletin C-
, Delegations of Lease Acquisition Authority - Notiﬁcation, Usage, and Reporting Requirements for General Purpose, Categorial, and Special Purpose Space Delegations. gov/portal/content/

The regulations and directives outlined in IRM
are necessary to ad- minister the FMSS RPM Program: a. FMR, Chapter
, Subchapter C, Real Property (
Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Ch.
). Parts
through

prescribe policies and procedures for agencies operating under the authority of GSA, or occupying government-owned or leased space under the control of GSA, including: facility management; maintenance and alterations; design and construction; utility services; assignment and utilization of space, pricing policy for occupancy in GSA space; real estate acquisition; ﬁre and life safety; environmental management; and security http://www.gsa.gov/fmr b. GSA Pricing Desk Guide, Latest Edition governs the pricing of GSA’s real estate and related services, including agency rights and responsibilities under various types of occupancy. c. GSA Customer Guide to Real Property explains how to request, use, and service GSA-controlled space. d. GSA Leasing Desk Guide, contains authorities, policies, technical and cedural guides, and administrative limitations governing the acquisition by lease of real property. e. Treasury Directive
, Acquisition, Utilization, and Disposal of Treasury Real Property Assets, September

, contains provisions for the Treasury Department’s acquisition, management, and disposal of real property assets by utilizing prudent asset management practices that opti- mize utilization of space. f. Treasury Directive
, Location of New Offices and Facilities in Rural Areas, July
, requires that ﬁrst priority be given to locating new Treasury facilities in rural areas. g. FMR, Subchapter C, Real Property, Part
“Location of Space” (
CFR Ch.

), contains provisions for ensuring that executive follow certain statutes, regulations and policies when identifying a geo- graphic service area and the delineated area within which it wishes to lo- cate speciﬁc activities, consistent with its mission and program requirements. h. Executive Order
, Federal Space Management, August

, requires agencies with mission needs for space in urban areas to give consideration to centralized community business areas and adjacent of similar character, including other speciﬁc areas which may be recom- mended by local officials, except when such selection is otherwise prohibited. i. Executive Order
, Locating Federal Facilities on Historic Properties in Our Nation’s Central Cities, May
, encourages federal to locate facilities on historic properties in central cities. j. Executive Order
, Government Work Space Management Reforms, March

, requires agencies to establish programs to produce and maintain an inventory of work space and related furnishings, reduce the amount of work space used or held to essential minimums, utilize all agency furnishings in a manner that reﬂects a judicious employment of public moneys; and report to the Administrator of General Services any holdings not necessary for the mission of the agency. k. Executive Order
, Federal Real Property Asset Management, ary

, requires agencies to designate a Senior Real Property who will be responsible for implementing and developing a continuous comprehensive Asset Management Plan (AMP) process for the agency. This process includes identifying and categorizing all real property owned, Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
F

leased or otherwise managed by the agency; prioritizing actions to be taken to improve the operational and ﬁnancial management of the agen- cy’s real property inventory, and using public and commercial and best practices to periodically evaluate all assets, among other items. l. Executive Order
, Strengthening Federal Environmental, Energy, Transportation Management, January

, requires agencies to de- velop and implement sustainable practices in the construction, operation, and maintenance of federal facilities including: energy efficiency, of sustainable and renewable energy resources, reduction of greenhouse gases, water conservation, pollution and waste prevention, and recycling, among other items. m. Public Law
, Energy Independence and Security Act of

, tains provisions and requirements for the management and reporting of energy requirements for leased buildings under the control of GSA and agencies via delegated lease management authority, as well as for buildings. n. FMR Amendment
, FMR Case
“Real Property Update – Smoking Restrictions” (
CFR Part
), contains for the restrictions on the smoking of tobacco products in leased or space under the jurisdiction, custody, or control of the Administrator of General Services. o. Executive Order
, Planning for Federal Sustainability in the Next cade, March

, requires agencies to achieve targeted goals in tainability in the operation of federal facilities and ﬂeets. Emphasis is on energy and water use, greenhouse gas emissions, carbon footprint, recy- cling, minimization of hazardous materials and chemical pollution, retroﬁt of federal facilities maximizing use of energy efficient and sustainable practices, and minimizing the environmental impact on communities federal facilities are located, among other items. p. FMR Bulletin
-B

, “Guidelines for Alternative Workplace Arrange- ments″, establishes guidelines for implementing and operating Alternative Workplace Arrangements (AWA). These guidelines are designed to assist agencies in the design and operation of AWA programs as well as to re- solve AWA issues commonly faced by agencies. q. Public Law
Telework Enhancement Act of

The Act is a key factor in the Federal Government’s ability to achieve greater ﬂexibility in managing its workforce through the use of telework. Telework programs provide agencies a valuable tool to meet mission objectives while helping employees enhance work/life effectiveness. Speciﬁcally, telework is a ful strategy to improve continuity of operations to help ensure that essen- tial federal functions continue during emergency situations; promotes management effectiveness when telework is used to target reductions in management costs and environmental impact and transit costs; and en- hances work-life balance. r. Executive Order
, Promoting Efficient Spending, November

, requires agencies to develop and monitor plans to reduce administrative and operating costs in several areas including: travel, extraneous promo- tional items, employee information technology devices, printing, and em- ployee relocation expenses and to maximize use of electronic communications to the maximum extent practicable in conducting Federal Government business. s. General Services Administration Acquisition Regulation (GSAR) Part
Acquiring Leasehold Interests in Real Property. The GSAR is included in Internal Revenue Manual
General Services Administration Acquisition Regulation (GSAR) Part 570 Acquiring Leasehold Interests in Real Property. The GSAR is included in
the GSA Acquisition Manual (GSAM). GSAM Part
is applicable to agencies who receive delegated leasing authority from GSA. t. Public Law
- Public Buildings Act of

, As Amended Certain leasing actions that GSA undertakes on behalf of federal agencies require congressional authorization if the net annual rent under a lease contract exceeds a certain value. The value, known as the prospectus threshold, is established annually by GSA and approved by Congress. Net annual rent excludes operating expenses, deﬁned as services and utilities necessary for occupancy. Net annual rent includes ﬁxed expenses such as real es- tate taxes or escrows or reserves for capital improvements and/or replacement. Additionally, congressional authorization is required for space alterations in leased space if the value of the alterations exceeds one-half of the prospectus threshold. The types of leased space alteration projects subject to the prospectus threshold include: alterations for any agency af- ter initial occupancy by that agency; alterations to prepare vacant space for backﬁll by any agency other than the original tenant agency; and im- provement to building systems or architectural features after initial occupancy. Architectural, design, and construction expenses are all con- sidered in determining whether an alterations project is applicable to the prospectus threshold. Moving expenses, temporary relocation costs, and furniture are not included in the project cost for prospectus purposes. The prospectus threshold is also applicable to space alterations in owned space: Real Property Asset Management Tools and GSA Annual Prospectus Thresholds. u. Public Law

- Competition in Contracting Act (CICA), CICA requires certain agencies to obtain full and open competition in the acquisition of supplies and services, including leased space. CICA is applicable to agen- cies who receive delegated leasing authority from GSA. v. General Services Administration General Reference Guide for Real Prop- erty Policy (October
). IRS must adhere to other applicable laws, regulations and executive orders pertaining to real property acquisition, use and management. https://www.gsa.gov/portal/content/

) The Director, FMSS in conjunction with the Deputy Director, FMSS, has responsibility as it relates to the management of real property for: a. development and administration of a long-term space and housing strategy for IRS. b. determining objectives, practices, and standards for RPM throughout c. ensuring that effective space utilization is promoted throughout the IRS. d. ensuring space management best practices are implemented throughout FMSS. e. assisting the Chief, Agency-Wide Shared Services (AWSS) in administer- ing the IRS rent budget. f. ensuring alignment and compatibility of actions within the IRS strategic plans and business visions. g. monitoring functional compliance with service level agreements and balanced measures systems. h. developing strategies for improving functional service delivery to Units (BU) including resolution of issues of mutual concern. i. developing and maintaining external contacts, including Treasury, DHS, ISC, National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU), GSA, National
The Director, FMSS in conjunction with the Deputy Director, FMSS, has responsibility as it relates to the management of real property for:
a. development and administration of a long

term space and housing strategy for IRS. b. determining objectives, practices, and standards for RPM throughout c. ensuring that effective space utilization is promoted throughout the IRS. d. ensuring space management best practices are implemented throughout FMSS. e. assisting the Chief, Agency
Wide Shared Services (AWSS) in administer

ing the IRS rent budget. f. ensuring alignment and compatibility of actions within the IRS strategic plans and business visions. g. monitoring functional compliance with service level agreements and balanced measures systems. h. developing strategies for improving functional service delivery to Units (BU) including resolution of issues of mutual concern. i. developing and maintaining external contacts, including Treasury, DHS, ISC, National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU), GSA, National and Records Administration (NARA), professional organizations, and tractors.
Property Management Program 1.14.6

The FMSS Associate Director, Security Policy, is responsible for: a. planning, developing, evaluating, and controlling the Physical Security program. b. ensuring collaboration between Security Policy and Project Management to verify security requirements are considered during project planning and implementation. c. providing physical security policy, program guidance, oversight and assis

tance to area and territory offices. d. ensuring Security Work Authorizations (SWA) and all physical security funding aspects are reconciled. The Associate Directors (AD), Operations, are responsible for: a. providing RPM services to all customers through the Territory Managers (TM) in their respective geographical areas of responsibility. b. ensuring timely execution of space management program activities, mining appropriate strategies to achieve FMSS, BU, and IRS program goals c. managing resources and ensuring proper application of IRS and government

wide real property policies and regulations. d. working with BU representatives to identify customer needs, meet service demands, resolve customer problems, implement service level and ensure effective utilization of space and resources. e. managing improvements in FMSS business processes and systems. f. formulating, executing, and monitoring facilities management support funds, in conjunction with the TM and the AWSS AD for Technology & In

vestments Strategy (TIS) and Financial Management Branch (FMB). g. working with GSA and other public officials to resolve issues impacting FMSS service delivery. h. implementing physical security policy for their respective territory offices. The AD, RPM, is responsible for: a. developing and implementing guidance, procedures, objectives, practices and standards for the administration, management and oversight of the

The Associate Directors (AD), Operations, are responsible for: a. providing RPM services to all customers through the Territory Managers (TM) in their respective geographical areas of responsibility. b. ensuring timely execution of space management program activities, mining appropriate strategies to achieve FMSS, BU, and IRS program goals c. managing resources and ensuring proper application of IRS and government

wide real property policies and regulations. d. working with BU representatives to identify customer needs, meet demands, resolve customer problems, implement service level and ensure effective utilization of space and resources. e. managing improvements in FMSS business processes and systems. f. formulating, executing, and monitoring facilities management support funds, in conjunction with the TM and the AWSS AD for Technology & vestments Strategy (TIS) and Financial Management Branch (FMB). g. working with GSA and other public officials to resolve issues impacting FMSS service delivery. h. implementing physical security policy for their respective territory offices. The AD, RPM, is responsible for: a. developing and implementing guidance, procedures, objectives, and standards for the administration, management and oversight of the IRS real property, space management and delegated leasing programs. b. developing and administering long

term space and housing strategy. c. developing and managing IRS AMP through the Chief, Portfolio and Management, who reports to the AD, RPM. An AMP allows for a ous integrated strategy between RPM and the territories to effectively manage the real estate portfolio. d. facilitating the integration of Design & Strategic Campus Planning FMSS requirements into the long

term space and housing strategy for campus locations. e. reviewing and approving IRS space requests. f. negotiating, reviewing and approving IRS OA. g. accurately maintaining data for rent, leases and OA in the Graphic Database Interface (GDI) application. h. tracking the inventory of IRS space holdings, forecasting rent for current and future years, monitoring actual rent expenses, verifying the of GSA bills and ensuring that billing errors get corrected. i. ensuring that IRS real estate management practices are consistent with presidential directives and executive orders, federal laws, regulations policies.

physical security policy for their respective territory

, Location of Space, (
CFR Part

). k. representing IRS with Treasury, GSA, contractors, industry trade and fessional organizations, and other stakeholders regarding the of real estate and other cross-functional issues. l. providing real property and space management subject matter expert training and technical support to FMSS staff. m. managing and executing the IRS real property lease contracting using authority delegated by GSA, Treasury and IRS Procurement, including acquisition and administration of leased space by Real Leasing Officers and management of the acquired space in conjunction with territory Contracting Officer’s Representatives (COR), as well as re- sponding to any legal protests or litigation resulting from the program. (

) The AD, Project Management, is responsible for: a. managing FMSS programs for project development, prioritization and approval of space projects, including the Project Investment Fund. b. developing the National Workspace Standards (NWS) and working in junction with DSCP, FMSS, on office design guides for different types of space. c. developing work space improvements and innovative housing solutions under the Servicewide Workplace Strategies initiative. d. providing SOP, training and resources to continuously improve IRS work space through effective and efficient project delivery. e. developing innovative and sustainable furniture design and acquisition cedures. f. ensuring collaboration between Project Management and Security Policy to verify security requirements are considered during project planning implementation. (

) The AD, Design and Strategic Campus Planning (DSCP), is responsible for: a. strategic planning of the campus space portfolio. b. working with TM to review the campus real estate portfolio related to mission processing sites to maximize utilization of space. c. executing major space projects associated with the campus portfolio as campus replacement or major repair and alterations. d. development and management of the Buildings Delegation Program, including determining objectives, budget, practices and standards for building and energy management in accordance with the terms of GSA delegation agreements with Treasury and IRS, and approval of new, amended, and expiring delegations. e. delivering architectural, engineering, construction design and cost ing services for FMSS. f. developing and maintaining the IRS Facilities Design Criteria. g. assisting Project Management in the development of office design for different types of space. h. ensuring that all IRS operations and occupied facilities are managed, maintained and operated in accordance with IRS Environment, Health Safety Policy, P-

) The directives in IRM

must be adhered to in the administration of the FMSS RPM Program. a. The IRS FMSS NWS will be utilized when acquiring or altering space. IRS Facilities Design Criteria and the IRS-FMSS Office Design Handbook will be utilized when space is constructed for occupancy by IRS and will be considered to the maximum extent practicable for existing space. tionally, the IRS-FMSS Career Management and Learning Centers Training Space and IRS-FMSS Taxpayer Assistance Center (TAC) Guides must be used for the design of these specialized facilities. Due to security concerns, the IRS does not fund the construction of restroom fa- cilities for general public use within IRS assigned space. b. The AMP will be used as the basis for development of projects that best serve the mission of IRS within resource limitations. Portfolio and Rent Management, RPM, will ensure that an AMP is developed and completed in accordance with published guidance and managerial direction and will be responsible for tracking, maintaining and consolidating the asset man- agement data for the IRS portfolio. DSCP has responsibility for campus planning where submission processing functions are performed. c. Form FMSS-
, IRS FMSS Request For Space, will be used to request space from GSA or to lease space under delegated GSA authority. All FMSS-
forms must be submitted for review and approval to the FMSS, or designee, in accordance with Delegation Order
, Requests for Space and Occupancy Agreement, and other existing FMSS d. GSA Form

, Reimbursable Work Authorization (RWA), will be used request arrangements from GSA for tenant improvements and building services which are otherwise not included in rent, as well as for special projects on an as-needed basis. All RWA must be approved by the TM, designee. The FMB must certify funding through the Integrated Procure- ment System (IPS) prior to submission to GSA. e. The FMSS GDI system Rent Module provides both current ﬁscal and out year data for the IRS rent budget, allowing FMSS to project the IRS rent budget requirements. The GDI Rent Module is also utilized to validate GSA rent charges. f. The provisions contained in Federal Management Regulation (FMR), chapter C, Real Property, Part
, Delegation of Authority (
CFR Part
) and FMR Bulletin C-

“Delegations of Lease Acquisition Authority – Notiﬁcation, Usage, and Reporting Requirements for General Purpose, Categorical, and Special Purpose Space Delegations” will be followed and utilized by the FMSS delegated leasing program under the authority granted by GSA. g. “Real Property Policies Update – Smoking Restrictions” (

) address smoking in federally owned and leased buildings. Further, IRS does not fund the construction of indoor or outdoor smoking areas. IRS does support and facilitate smoking cessation programs. k. The provisions contained in FMR Bulletin

, “Guidelines for Alterna- tive Workplace Arrangements″, established guidelines for implementing and operating AWA. These guidelines are designed to assist agencies in the design and operation of AWA programs as well as to resolve AWA issues commonly faced by agencies. These guidelines should be utilized in conjunction with FMSS provisions for out of the office employees.
